title.value: Transitions between cognitive topographies: contributions of network structure, neuromodulation, and disease
title.justification: This is the title of the research paper provided.
title.quote: Transitions between cognitive topographies: contributions of network structure, neuromodulation, and disease

extractions.description: This paper investigates how the architecture of the human connectome shapes transitions between various cognitive activation patterns. The study integrates large-scale neuroimaging data, including fMRI, diffusion tractography, cortical morphometry, and PET, to simulate transitions between brain states and how these transitions can be reshaped by pathological and pharmacological perturbations.

type.justification: The paper employs experimental data from multiple large-scale neuroimaging modalities to draw its conclusions.
type.quote: Integrating large-scale multimodal neuroimaging data from functional MRI, diffusion tractography, cortical morphometry, and positron emission tomography, we simulate how anatomically-guided transitions between cognitive states can be reshaped by pharmacological or pathological perturbation.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on analyzing and understanding the brain's network architecture and how it influences cognitive topographies.
name.quote: Network control allows us to ask how brain network structure supports transitions between cognitively-relevant brain states.

name.justification: The research extensively utilizes fMRI data to map brain activity and understand cognitive functions.
name.quote: Large-scale, noninvasive techniques like functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) provides a way to map activation patterns to cognitive functions.

name.justification: The study employs computational models to simulate brain state transitions and their energetic costs.
name.quote: Network control theory is a computational paradigm that explicitly operationalises how the architecture and dynamics of a network supports transitions between activation states.

name.justification: The paper investigates the role of neurotransmitter receptor densities in shaping brain state transitions.
name.quote: We also systematically incorporate neurotransmitter receptor density maps (18 receptors and transporters).

name.justification: This model is used to quantify the cost of transitioning between cognitive topographies based on structural connectome data.
name.quote: Network control theory is a computational paradigm that explicitly operationalises how the architecture and dynamics of a network supports transitions between activation states.

is_contributed.justification: Network Control Theory is already established in the field; the paper utilizes it but does not claim to have developed it.
is_contributed.quote: Originally developed in the physics and engineering literature, network control theory conceptualises the state of a dynamical system at a given time as a linear function of three elements: (i) the previous state, (ii) the structural network linking system units, and (iii) input injected into the system to control it.

is_executed.justification: The research involves applying network control theory to empirical neuroimaging data.
is_executed.quote: We define the cognitive topographies as meta-analytic brain activation patters from the NeuroSynth atlas (Methods). With definitions of the network and its state in hand, we consider the problem of network controllability: how can the system be driven to specific target states by internal or external control inputs?

is_compared.justification: The study focuses on applying Network Control Theory rather than comparing it numerically to other models.
is_compared.quote: Although the brain is a nonlinear system, it has been shown that non-linear dynamics can be locally approximated by linear dynamics [26, 62], including through the application of dynamic causal models [40, 41].

referenced_paper_title.justification: This work is foundational to the field and is referenced in the context of explaining Network Control Theory.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Liu, Y.-Y., Slotine, J.-J., and Barabási, A.-L. (2011). Controllability of complex networks. Nature.

name.justification: The NeuroSynth dataset provides meta-analytic brain activation maps associated with various cognitive terms, which are used to define cognitive topographies in the study.
name.quote: We define cognitive topographies (i.e., cognitively relevant brain states) as meta-analytic patterns of cortical activation pertaining to over 100 cognitive terms, obtained by aggregating over 15 000 functional MRI studies from the NeuroSynth atlas.

referenced_paper_title.value: Large-scale automated synthesis of human functional neuroimaging data
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper by Yarkoni et al. is foundational for understanding and using the NeuroSynth dataset in neuroimaging studies.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Yarkoni, T. et al., (2011). Large-scale automated synthesis of human functional neuroimaging data. Nature Methods, 8(8), 665-670.

name.justification: The ENIGMA consortium's dataset provides cortical thickness data used to simulate the effects of disease-related perturbations on cognitive transitions.
name.quote: We focus on cortical thickness by making the simplifying assumption that the amount of input energy that a region is capable of injecting into the network is a function of its total number of excitatory neurons—and that this, in turn, is related to cortical thickness. This approach is conceptually related to the approach recently employed by Singleton and colleagues [124], who applied non-uniform control inputs according to the normalised density of the serotonin 2A receptor expressed in each region (as quantified by PET).

referenced_paper_title.value: The enigma consortium: large-scale collaborative analyses of neuroimaging and genetic data
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper by Thompson et al. outlines the goals and methodology of the ENIGMA consortium, which is crucial for contextualizing its datasets.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Thompson, P. M., et al. (2014). The enigma consortium: large-scale collaborative analyses of neuroimaging and genetic data. Brain Imaging and Behavior, 8, 153-182.

name.justification: The HCP dataset provides the structural connectome used to study the energetic cost of transitioning between cognitive states.
name.quote: We define the network whose activity is to be controlled as the human structural connectome (obtained as a consensus of N = 100 Human Connectome Project [148] subjects’ connectomes reconstructed from diffusion MRI tractography; see Methods).

referenced_paper_title.value: The wu-minn human connectome project: An overview
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper by Van Essen et al. provides crucial background on the methodology and objectives of the HCP, which is utilized in the study for structural connectome data.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Van Essen, D. C., et al. (2013). The wu-minn human connectome project: An overview. NeuroImage, 80, 62-79.

name.justification: SPM is mentioned as being used for nonlinear registration in the preprocessing of diffusion MRI data.
name.quote: QSDR first reconstructs diffusion-weighted images in native space and computes the quantitative anisotropy (QA) in each voxel. These QA values are used to warp the brain to a template QA volume in Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) space using a nonlinear registration algorithm implemented in the statistical parametric mapping (SPM) software.

referenced_paper_title.value: Statistical Parametric Mapping: The Analysis of Functional Brain Images
referenced_paper_title.justification: SPM is a well-known library in neuroimaging and this paper is a comprehensive resource on its applications.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Friston, K.J., et al. (2006). Statistical Parametric Mapping: The Analysis of Functional Brain Images. Academic Press.
